===Alliant Credit Union (HealthEquity)=== [https://www.alliantcreditunion.org/depositsinvestments/healthsavings/ Alliant Credit Union] has no fees to open the account, no monthly or management fees, no transaction fees, free checks, free VISA debit card, no minimums, no fees to close the account. Alliant is ideal for a "cash" HSA to pay ongoing medical expenses or a starter HSA while you build towards an "investment" HSA. The HSA can be invested for a $5.95 monthly fee, with at least $1000 remaining in the cash account. Options include several Vanguard funds.
Note: Starting October 5, 2017, Alliant's HSA will be transitioned to HealthEquity. See this {{Forum post|t=227963|title=Alliant Credit Union no longer offering HSAs as of 11/9}} and [https://www.healthequity.com/alliant/members/ Alliant HSAs now administered by HealthEquity].
===BenefitWallet===
As of April 2024, BenefitWallet HSAs have been transitioned to [[#Health_Equity|HealthEquity]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.healthequity.com/benefitwallet2/members/|title=Welcome to HealthEquity|publisher=HealthEquity|accessdate=July 7, 2024}}</ref>
=== Discovery Benefits (WEX) ===
The Discovery Benefits (Wex) HSA is only offered through employer plans.
Terms and fees may vary from one company to another, so be sure to verify this information for your own employer. To view the fee schedule, log in to your account, then click the "Get Help" link which takes you into a help site. From there, in the search function search for "fee". You should see a search result for "Article ID: PROD-2175 | Health Savings Account (HSA) custodial management fee FAQ" which explains the general fees.
For at least one Discovery Benefits HSA member, the "The custodial management fee is a flat fee of 25 basis points per year that is assessed quarterly. This equates to 0.0625% each quarter on any dollars currently invested in mutual funds... The HealthcareBank interest-bearing account is excluded from this fee." There are no low-balance fees in the savings account, or other fees. As noted, the fee schedule may vary from one company to another, depending on the terms negotiated between each company and Discovery Benefits.
If your HSA balance is low, then the fees are lower than many employer-based HSAs that charge a flat monthly fee. But since the fee is assessed as a percentage on your balance, then the higher your balance, the greater your fees. For this reason, if you wish to avoid these fees, it would be advisable to perform an annual HSA transfer or rollover to a no-fee HSA.
==== Discovery Benefits Investment Platform ====
The investing platform is available for any HSA balance over $1,000. You can set up automated investing so that any balance over the minimum is automatically invested. The platform contains multiple Vanguard index funds in the institutional share class, as well as Target Retirement date funds.
See also: {{Forum post|t=298955 |title=Discovery Benefits (Wex) HSA - fees?|date=31 July 2020}}.
===Elements Financial (Eli Lilly Federal Credit Union)=== Formerly known as Eli Lilly Federal Credit Union,<ref group="note">Eli Lilly Federal Credit Union changed its name to Elements Financial on January 6, 2015. Source: [https://www.elements.org/elfcu-has-proudly-become-elements-financial/ Elfcu has proudly become… Elements Financial], viewed September 20, 2017.</ref> Elements Financial has no setup fees. A maintenance fee of $4/month applies for balances below $2,500.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.elements.org/media/3312/elementsfeeschedule.pdf|title=Fee Schedule|publisher=Elements Financial|accessdate=July 7, 2024}}</ref> Access to investments through [https://www.drivewealth.com DriveWealth] is available only if your account balance ''at time of enrollment'' is at least $2,500.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.elements.org/personal/savings/health-savings-account/|title=Health Savings Accounts|publisher=Elements Financial|accessdate=July 7, 2024|quote=Elements Financial HSA members have access to an investment program through DriveWealth. Those who do not plan to use all of their HSA funds for current year medical expenses may wish to consider investing HSA dollars for potential added savings. To invest, you must have an account balance of at least $2,500 in your HSA at the time of enrollment.}}</ref>
===Fidelity=== [https://www.fidelity.com/go/hsa/why-hsa Fidelity] offers HSAs for employers and, as of November 2018, individuals.<ref>{{Forum post|t=263661|title=Rumor mill - Fidelity starting individual HSA's Nov. 15th|date=11 Nov 2018}}</ref> Individual HSAs have no account opening or transaction fees.<ref name="fide_HSA-">{{Cite web |title=HSA - Health Savings Account - Benefits {{!}} Fidelity |author= |work=Fidelity Investments |date= |access-date=18 November 2018 |url= https://www.fidelity.com/go/hsa/why-hsa}}, Footnote 4.</ref> In a favorable review of the Fidelity HSA's features, the [[The Finance Buff]] wrote: "No other HSA provider comes close to what Fidelity offers."<ref>{{Cite web | title=Best HSA Provider for Investing HSA Money |author=[[The Finance Buff]]| access-date=21 November 2018| date=19 November 2018 | url=https://thefinancebuff.com/best-hsa-provider-for-investing-hsa-money.html}}</ref>
===Health Equity=== [https://healthequity.com/ Health Equity] Includes many Vanguard index funds, along with a annual 0.396% fee on the balance (0.033% per month times 12 months).<ref>{{Forum post|t=146311|title=Health Equity HSA--New Passive Plan}}, 5 September 2014</ref>
===HSA Bank=== [https://www.hsabank.com HSA Bank] now has its own automatic investments with many different mutual funds and ETFs available. There is a fee of 0.10% unless $7500 is kept in cash in the account or your employer has an arrangement which waives the fee.
===Lively=== [https://livelyme.com/ Lively] offers a [[Charles Schwab]] (formerly [[TD Ameritrade]]) brokerage account which offers commission-free trades on over 100 ETFs (excluding Vanguard). There is no fee to invest (beginning on January 1, 2019)<ref name="live_No-F">{{Cite web |title=No-Fee HSA - Lively |author= |work=Lively |date= |access-date=21 December 2018 |url= https://livelyme.com/no-fee-hsa/}}</ref><ref name="busi_Live">{{Cite web |title=Lively Drops Investment Fees, Offers No-Fee Health Savings Account |author= |work=businesswire.com |date=20 December 2018 |access-date=21 December 2018 |url= https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20181220005189/en/Lively-Drops-Investment-Fees-Offers-No-Fee-Health}}</ref>; prior to 2019, there was a $2.50 monthly fee but no minimum cash balance.<ref>{{Forum post|t=228522|title=New HSA provider Lively offers investments for $30/yr fee|date=26 September 2017}}</ref>
===Optum Bank=== [https://www.optumbank.com/ Optum Bank] Offers a suite of some 20 investment options, including Admiral shares of Vanguard's 500, mid-cap, and small-cap indexes. Monthly fee but no asset-based fee. Minimum $2,000 cash in order to invest, and you cannot directly spend investment funds.
===Saturna Capital=== [https://www.saturna.com/individual/hsa/ Saturna Capital] offers a stand-alone brokerage account through Pershing. You do not need a separate bank account with the HSA. There is no monthly maintenance fee. Vanguard and Fidelity Spartan funds are available for $14.95 per trade. Saturna does not offer checks or HSA credit cards.<ref>{{Forum post|t=135513|title=my review of my HSA with Saturna brokerage|date=18 Mar 2014}}</ref> Saturna Capital's brokerage account has a $10 surcharge for Vanguard funds, as well as other fund families. The list can be found here: [https://www.saturna.com/sbs/fundvest_families.shtml FundVest Focus Fund Families]<ref>Health savings account [[Talk:Health savings account#Reader feedback: Saturna Capital's brokerage... | Discussion page]].</ref>
===SelectAccount=== [https://www.selectaccount.com/ SelectAccount] offers two levels of investment options. Once a minimum of $1,000 in an HSA savings account is achieved, you can open a basic investment account. Vanguard and Fidelity funds are among the choices in the [https://hsainvestments.com/fundperformance/?p=HSA HSA Investment Options]. Account balances above $10,000 may use a self-directed brokerage account with [[Charles Schwab]]. (You must keep at least $1,000 in the base balance of your HSA account.) Both investment options impose an $18/year management fee. Schwab's [https://www.schwab.com/public/schwab/investing/pricing_services/fees_minimums#tradeCommissions standard brokerage commission schedule] applies to transactions in the self-directed brokerage account.<ref>[https://www.selectaccount.com/wp-content/uploads/HSA-Reference-Guide.pdf HSA-Reference-Guide], pages 46 - 48, viewed October 22, 2017.</ref>
===The Sterling HSA=== [https://www.sterlinghsa.com/ The Sterling HSA] offers full-service medical record keeping with the Standard Plan, and the ability to use any brokerage account which is willing to open an account in the name of "Sterling HSA for The Benefit of (account holder)"when using the eSavings Plan. [https://www.sterlinghsa.com/products/hsa/individual Sterling HSA Fee Schedule] (there is an [https://www.sterlinghsa.com/products/hsa/investment_services/ additional $16 annual fee] for using their brokerage). Vanguard will not setup an account in accordance with Sterling HSA specifications.<ref>See [[Talk:Health savings account]], reader feedback.</ref>
===WageWorks=== [https://www.wageworks.com WageWorks] is a an employee benefits system that includes an HSA. Unlike Fidelity, Lively and many other HSA custodians, an individual HSA holder cannot enroll in WageWorks independently of their job, only through their employer.
A WageWorks HSA has a low-interest FDIC-insured savings account and an optional separate investment account on the BNY Mellon platform for HSA investing. In order to invest, you must maintain at least $1,000 in the savings account, with any balance above that available for optional investing.
====WageWorks HSA Fees==== Depending on the specific terms of your plan, you might pay a $2.00 monthly fee if the balance in the savings account is under $5,000; some employers may pay all or part of this fee for their employees. There are no investment trading fees or fees to use the investment platform, beyond standard mutual fund expense ratios. WageWorks also charges an additional $3.95 monthly fee for account holders who are no longer employed by their employers; as such, an individual who is enrolled in a WageWorks HSA and who leaves their employer should transfer out of WageWorks to a different custodian and close their WageWorks HSA. Additionally, there is a $16.00 transfer of asset (TOA) to another custodian fee.<ref name="smar_">{{Cite web |title=WageWorks HSA Fee Schedule |author= |work=smart-hsa.com |date=1 April 2016 |access-date=22 January 2019 |url= https://www.smart-hsa.com/pdf/getpdf.asp?id=WW-0601_CustodyDisclosureDoc}}</ref>
====WageWorks HSA Investing==== In the investment platform, there are approximately 35 mutual funds in the following asset classes: Large Cap US Equity, Small and Mid-Cap US Equity, International Equity, Fixed Income, and All-in-One (target date and two Vanguard LifeStrategy funds).
Of interest to Boglehead investors are the following [[The Vanguard Group|Vanguard]] index funds, which are the only index funds in the platform:
* Vanguard 500 Index Admiral ({{MStarFundLink|VFIAX}}) * Vanguard Small Cap Index Admiral ({{MStarFundLink|VSMAX}}) * Vanguard Developed Markets Index Admiral ({{MStarFundLink|VTMGX}}) * Vanguard Emerging Markets Index Admiral ({{MStarFundLink|VEMAX}}) * Vanguard Short Term Investment Grade ({{MStarFundLink|VFSTX}}) * Vanguard Long-Term Bond Index Investor ({{MStarFundLink|VBLTX}}) * Vanguard LifeStrategy Moderate Growth Investor ({{MStarFundLink|VSMGX}}) * Vanguard LifeStrategy Conservative Growth Investor ({{MStarFundLink|VSCGX}})
Note that only the two listed [[Vanguard LifeStrategy Funds]] are included; Vanguard has two other LifeStrategy funds (Income and Growth) but they are not available in WageWorks. The other WageWorks funds are actively managed funds.
A WageWorks account holder may configure their account to automatically invest new contributions into designated funds, for hands-off account management.

{{for|a full discussion|wikipedia:Home insurance}}
'''{{PAGENAME}}''', [[renters' insurance]], and [[landlords' insurance]] generally provide coverage for loss of your own property and liability to others which occurred because of their presence on your property. Deductibles are usually available. While a homeowner is paying off a mortgage on their house the lender will usually require homeowner's insurance, as may a buyer during the process of selling the house.
There are always excluded perils, which means that if the loss is caused by one of those items then the insurance provides no coverage. There may be ways to cover these exclusions, either by riders amending the standard policy for an additional fee or by purchasing specialty insurance such as [[earthquake insurance|earthquake]] or [[flood insurance]].
==Types of homeowner's insurance==
Standard policies are often referred to as:<ref>[http://www.scc.virginia.gov/boi/pubs/hoguide.pdf Homeowners Insurance Guide], Commonwealth of Virginia SCC Bureau of Insurance </ref> *HO-2 Broad Form (Named Peril)- a basic policy covering 16 or more common disasters.<ref group="note"> These enumerated perils include: 1.Fire and lightning 2. Removal of property endangered by any insured peril 3. Windstorm 4. Hail 5. Explosion 6. Riot and civil commotion 7. Vehicle or aircraft damage to your property 8. Smoke 9. Vandalism and malicious mischief 10. Breakage of glass 11. Theft 12. Falling objects 13. Weight of ice, snow or sleet damage 14. Collapse of building and any part thereof 15. Sudden and accidental damage, cracking, burning or bulging from steam or hot water heating system or appliances for heating water 16. Accidental discharge or overflow of water or steam from plumbing or heating systems 17. Freezing of plumbing, heating or air conditioning systems and domestic appliances 18. Sudden and accidental injury from artificially generated electrical currents 19. Limited coverage for trees, shrubs or plants 20. Additional living expenses 21. Personal liability insurance protection 22. Medical payments coverage </ref> *HO-3 Special Form- The typical, most comprehensive form used for single-family homes. This policy protects your home from all perils except those specifically excluded.<ref>[http://www.iii.org/articles/are-there-different-types-of-policies.html Are there different types of policies?], Insurance Information Institute </ref> *HO-4 Renters Insurance (Contents Broad Form)- this policy protects a renter's possessions, and can provide liability protection. *HO-5 Comprehensive Form (HO-3 with HO-15, Special Personal Property Coverage)- Covers the same as HO3 plus more. On this policy the contents are covered on an open peril basis, therefore as long as the cause of loss is not specifically excluded in the policy it will be covered for that cause of loss. *HO-6 Condominium Unit Owners - For condo and co-op owners, this policy provides coverage for both your belongings and the structural parts of the building that you own. *MV Market Value or Older Homes Forms (Modified Coverage Form)- usually this coverage will be based on an actual cash value basis (replacement minus depreciation).
The homeowners policy contains two sections. Section I provides property coverages (A, B, C and D) while Section II provides liability coverages (E and F). A brief description of the individual coverages follows:<ref>[http://www.insurance.ca.gov/0100-consumers/0060-information-guides/0040-residential/residential-insurance.cfm#gettingthe Consumers:residential insurance], California Department of Insurance: </ref>
*Coverage A - Dwelling *Coverage B - Other Structures *Coverage C - Personal Property *Coverage D - Loss of Use *Coverage E - Personal Liability *Coverage F - Medical Payments to Others
The typical policy has the following limits on coverage:
{| class="wikitable" |+ Typical Policy Limits<ref>[http://www.insureuonline.org/consumer_guide_home.pdf NAIA Consumer's Guide to Home Insurance]</ref> ! Coverage Component ! Typical Limits |- | Dwelling | You choose |- | Other Structures | 10% of Dwelling coverage limit |- | Personal Property | 50% of Dwelling coverage limit |- | Loss of Use |20% of Dwelling coverage limit |- | Personal Liability | You choose |- | Medical Payments | You choose |}
==Replacement cost vs. market value== When insuring the value of a home, homeowner's can usually choose among three levels of coverage.
*'''Actual cash value''' - This value covers the house plus the value of your belongings after deducting depreciation. *'''Replacement cost''' - This is the actual cash value without the deduction for depreciation. *'''Guaranteed (or extended) replacement cost''' - This policy pays whatever it costs to repair or build your home. Some insurers only offer extended replacement insurance, providing for a 20-25% increase over the replacement cost value.<ref> [http://www.investopedia.com/articles/pf/08/homeowner-insurance.asp#ixzz1f0eX7A2s The Beginner's Guide To Homeowners' Insurance], investopedia, (January 23, 2011) </ref>
==Discounts and deductibles== There are a number of steps a policyholder can take to reduce the cost of homeowner's insurance without reducing the amount of coverage. Insurance companies may provide discounts for the following actions:<ref name="twelveways"> [http://www.iinc.org/articles/33/1/Twelve-Ways-To-Lower-Your-Homeowners-Insurance-Costs/Page1.html Twelve Ways to Lower Your Homeowner's Insurance Costs] </ref> * Adding smoke detectors, fire extinguishers, dead bolts and burglar alarms can often result in a discount. * Some insurer's will discount homeowner insurance premiums if you also insure your automobile with the company. * Discounts are often available to non-smokers and senior citizens. * Discounts are often available if you stay with the same insurer for many years.
The insurance premium can also be reduced by increasing the deductible you are willing to pay for each claim. Deductibles on homeowners policies usually start at $250. Depending upon the insurer, deductibles can be reduced as follows: * increasing your deductible to $500, you could save up to 12 percent; * increasing your deductible to $1,000, you could save up to 24 percent; * increasing your deductible to $2,500, you could save up to 30 percent; * increasing your deducible to $5,000, you could save up to 37 percent.<ref name="twelveways" />
==Hurricane deductible== The heavy damage associated with hurricanes and tropical storms has led insurance companies to levy a hurricane deductible assessed to claims associated with storm wind damage. The deductible is triggered only when there is a hurricane or tropical storm. Currently, eighteen states have the hurricane deductible: Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Texas, Virginia and Washington DC.<ref name="hurricane"> [http://www.iii.org/media/hottopics/insurance/hurricanwindstorm/ Hurricane and Windstorm Deductibles], Insurance Information Institute, September 2011. </ref>
The deductible can be either a dollar amount, or more commonly, a percentage amount (usually 1 to 5 percent, but can be higher in some coastal areas with high wind risk). In many states a policyholder may be given the option of paying a higher premium for a dollar deductible, but in high risk coastal areas the percentage deductible is usually mandatory.
{{blockquote|''Example'': Arthur and Mary have a homeowner's policy that includes a hurricane deductible since they live in a high risk coastal region of North Carolina. Their policy has a $500 standard deductible, so they must pay the first $500 of a standard claim out of pocket. The hurricane percentage deductibles are based on the home's insured value. Their house is insured for $200,000 and has a 5 percent hurricane deductible, so the first $10,000 of a claim due to storm damage must be paid out of their pocket.<ref name="hurricane" />}}

{{US}} {{for|a full discussion|wikipedia:Professional liability insurance}}
'''{{PAGENAME}}''', also called '''Professional Indemnity Insurance''', protects professional practitioners such as architects, lawyers, physicians, and accountants against potential negligence claims made by their patients/clients. Professional [[liability insurance]] may take on different names depending on the profession. For example, professional liability insurance in reference to the medical profession may be called Medical Malpractice.
Notaries public may take out errors and omissions insurance (E&O). Other potential E&O policyholders include real estate brokers, home inspectors, appraisers, and website developers. There are also specific E&O policies for technology companies, such as software developers, technology consultants and other creators of technology.
This coverage focuses on the failure to perform, financial loss and error or omission of the products or services sold. Additional coverage can be added for breach of warranty, intellectual property, personal injury, security and cost of contract.

{{US|non-US_link=[[Wikipedia:Life insurance]]}}
{{Notice | Life insurance products are complex in terms of pricing, contractual clauses, and taxation. This is a simplified overview of life insurance characteristics. Please ask in the forum for advice on any specific situations. Additional information can be found under ''External links'' [[#External links | below]]. }} '''Life insurance''' is a contract between the insured, the owner (who may also be the insured), and a life insurance company. The owner pays a stipulated premium to the insurance company. If the insured dies while the policy is in force a death benefit is paid to the beneficiary. Some policies accumulate cash value which is available by loan or upon surrender to the owner. Also, some policies have accelerated death benefits which may be available if the insured is expected to die within six months to a year.<ref>Definition of life insurance by forum member mephistophles (Lee E. Marshall), a Chartered Life Underwriter (CLU)</ref>
== Types of life insurance == Life insurance can broadly be divided into three general categories - "term", "permanent", and "group". Term life insurance is usually intended for "temporary" insurance needs, such as insuring a family breadwinner while others are dependent on their income. Permanent life insurance is usually intended for "lifetime" insurance needs or cash accumulation. Group life insurance is usually provided through an employer or other association, as opposed to term and permanent which are sold to individuals.
* '''Term life insurance''' usually provides a level death benefit for a certain number of years, at a premium rate guaranteed for the term period. For example, a typical 20 year term policy would provide a level death benefit, such as $1 million, for a period of 20 years, in exchange for a premium of $X per year. Level term insurance is typically sold for periods of 10-30 years, with the most popular periods being 15 and 20 years. (Note that a small number of term life insurance policies are sold with premiums that rise every year, 5 years, etc., and/or with death benefits that decrease over time.) Most policies sold as "level term life insurance" actually continue beyond the initial premium guarantee period at a much higher premium, but the insured can lapse the policy at any time and is not obligated to pay the much higher "post-level" premium rate. * '''Permanent life insurance''' provides a death benefit for the entirety of the insured's life. There are several types of permanent life insurance, as follows: ** '''Whole life insurance''' has a premium and death benefit that is fixed and guaranteed to be level for life. Because the chances of death increase as time goes on, the premiums paid in the early years exceed the probability of death, and therefore a "cash value" builds up within the policy over time. The policyholder can typically access the cash value by surrendering the policy, which terminates the insurance coverage, and can also take out "policy loans" from the insurance company, based on the security of the cash value. Most whole life policies are sold by "mutual" life insurance companies, and pay non-guaranteed "policyholder dividends" on an annual basis, which reduce the net cost of the whole life policy. The policyholder dividends can be used to reduce future premium payments, purchase additional insurance coverage, or just accumulate within the policy. ** '''Universal life''' is the general name for several life insurance products that use an "account value", which is a notional account maintained by the insurance company. Premiums paid by the policyholder are added to the account value (net of any premium loads). Deductions from the account value are made by the insurance company, generally on a monthly basis, for cost of insurance charges, rider charges, and any other expense loads. Additional credits to the account value are made with respect to interest or equity market returns on the account value. A universal life policy generally remains in force as long as the account value is positive, and lapses if the account value drops to zero. Most universal life products have "surrender charges" in the early durations of the policy, which reduce the amount available to the policyholder for loan or surrender. The policyholder can access the account value (net of surrender charges) by fully surrendering the policy, which terminates the insurance coverage, by making a "partial surrender" of the account value, or by taking out a policy loan. Within the general category of universal life, there are several distinct products as follows: *** '''Traditional universal life''' (or just plain "universal life" or "UL") credits interest to the account value at a rate declared by the company. The interest rate credited is guaranteed to not fall below a rate guaranteed in the policy (often 3%, but may be lower or higher). *** '''Indexed universal life''' (often referred to as "IUL") credits interest to the account value based on the performance of an external index, such as the S&P 500. The interest credited is limited by "caps" and "participation rates" declared by the insurance company. Usually, the interest credit is guaranteed to be not less than zero, even if the external index declines. *** '''Guaranteed universal life''' (often referred to as "GUL") works similar to traditional universal life. However, there is a "secondary guarantee" that the policy will not lapse, even if the account value falls below zero, so long as the premiums required by the policy are paid. GUL policies typically build minimal or zero cash values, and are therefore less expensive per dollar of death benefit than other types of permanent life insurance. *** '''Variable universal life''' (often referred to as "VUL") works similar to traditional universal life. However, rather than having the account value invested in the general funds of the insurance company, it is invested in mutual funds chosen by the policyholder. The account value can decline from year to year if the mutual funds decline in value. * '''Group life insurance''' is a product usually offered through an employer. It generally does not build cash values. Amounts offered may be a flat amount (such as $50,000 of death benefit), or a percentage of salary (typically 1X or 2X salary, subject to a maximum amount). Some employers offer additional amount of life insurance on a "voluntary" basis, often subject to individual underwriting. Group life coverage typically ends when the employment relationship ends, but most plans allow the employee to "convert" to an individual life insurance policy, usually at an extremely high premium. Many employers partially or fully pay the cost of group life insurance on their employees. Group life insurance is also offered through professional organizations such as engineers or accountants, often at very attractive premium rates. (See additional comments on group life insurance [[Life insurance#Further information on group life insurance|below]].)
== Purchasing individual life insurance == Most individual life insurance is sold through independent brokers or "tied" agents, while a few companies sell "direct to consumer".
* '''Independent brokers''' are "appointed" as agents for a number of life insurance companies, which allows them to submit applications for life insurance to the companies with which they are licensed. Such brokers often “shop” the coverage for a prospective insured to a number of different life insurers, trying to win the most favorable terms for their clients. While most independent brokers operate in a limited geographic area, some have established internet websites to allow them to solicit clients nationwide. * '''"Captive" agents''' primarily write life insurance for one life insurance company with which they are associated. Often the insurance company provides such agents with training, office space, etc. Such agents may also write a limited amount of business for other companies. Most captive agents are affiliated either with mutual life insurance companies, or with company groups that write both property and casualty insurance (homeowners, auto, etc.) and life insurance. * '''"Direct to consumer"''' sales use life insurance company employees who are also licensed as insurance agents to write applications for prospective policyholders.
Brokers and captive agents are usually compensated by commissions which are paid by the insurance company and whose cost is built into the pricing of the product. Life insurance commissions are generally “heaped” toward the first policy year, with renewal commissions at a much lower rate.
Depending on the amount of life insurance applied for and the age/health of the prospective insured, the life insurer might require a limited physical examination as a part of the application and underwriting process. For younger insureds and lower face amounts, the insurer might rely solely upon a questionnaire and an examination of medical and prescription drug records. Based on the underwriting review, the insurer will slot the applicant into a risk class, with lower premiums being charged to “better” risk classes. Certain conditions, usually medical in nature, might cause the insurer to assess “substandard” premiums above the standard quoted rate. The insurer also might decline to provide coverage to a prospective insured if the underwriting results are quite unfavorable. Insurers may view underwriting conditions differently, so agents may consider multiple insurers so that they can find the best rate for prospective insureds.
By law, the rates for any specific life insurance policy are identical no matter how the policy is bought. That is, the policy that is bought from "Company A", assuming the same specifications, will have the identical premium and terms whether you buy it through "Agent A", "Agent B", or any website.
Most life insurers have ratings from a firm called [https://web.ambest.com/home AM Best], which rates all insurance companies. The majority of companies that are competitively active in writing life insurance have ratings from AM Best of A- or higher, which should be adequately conservative for all life insurance policies except the very largest, where the insured might choose to divide coverage between two or more companies. Other rating agencies that cover insurance companies include Fitch Ratings, Standard & Poor's, and Moody's, but not all life insurers have ratings from each of the agencies.
== Tax treatment of life insurance == Under US tax law, death benefits from all types of life insurance are generally not taxable income to the beneficiary. Also, life insurance premiums are generally not a deductible expense.
For permanent life insurance policies, the growth in policy cash value is excluded from income, even though such growth may represent an increase in the policyholder's wealth. Cash surrenders from a permanent life insurance policy are ordinary taxable income to the extent that the cash surrender amount is higher than the "basis" of the policy (generally the cumulative premiums paid). In the case of partial surrenders, amounts received are treated first as a return of basis, with tax owed only on additional surrenders above the basis. Further, as with loans against most kinds of assets, loans secured by permanent life insurance policies are not treated as taxable income.
In some rare cases, a permanent life insurance policy may be classified as a "modified endowment contract" (MEC). In those cases, partial surrenders are taxed as income until all gain in the policy has been removed, and only then are partial surrenders taxed as a return of basis. Further, loans secured by modified endowment contracts are treated as surrenders or distributions. Most policyholders and life insurers try to avoid having policies classified as modified endowment contracts.
For US federal [[Estate and inheritance tax|estate and gift tax purposes]], which as of 2023 affects estates of single individuals valued over $12.92 million, death benefit proceeds from life insurance policies are generally includable in the decedent’s gross estate and hence are generally subject to the estate tax. Some families take steps to avoid this outcome, such as having other family members or specially designed “irrevocable life insurance trusts” own life insurance policies.
== Boglehead view of life insurance products == Based on observation of posts to the Boglehead Forum, following is the general view of Bogleheads on the topic of life insurance.
* '''Need for life insurance''' - Majority opinion is that life insurance is an appropriate financial tool for a person who has someone else dependent on their income and/or survival; for example, the breadwinner of a family or a parent caring for a child. However, life insurance is not generally recommended for a person who has no one dependent on their income or survival; for example, a single person with no dependents, or a child. * '''When is term life insurance appropriate''' - Majority opinion is that term life insurance is appropriate for the vast majority of life insurance needs, including, but not limited to: ** A family with young children might choose to insure the breadwinner(s) for a duration until the children are in college or on their own, to provide for the income that would be lost if the breadwinner were to die while the children are dependent. ** A family might also choose to insure a non-working parent, reflecting the additional cost of childcare or reduced income from the other parent if the non-working parent were to die while the children are dependent. ** A breadwinner might be insured to bridge to retirement, pension benefits, or Social Security availability for a non-working spouse. ** Note that some may choose to "ladder" term life insurance policies, purchasing (for example) both a 10 year and 20 year policy, to provide more insurance during the first 10 years and reduced coverage thereafter as needs change and the assets of the family increase. * '''When is permanent life insurance appropriate''' - Majority opinion is that permanent life insurance is appropriate for only a relatively small subset of the population. Such situations include, but are not limited to: ** Those who have children with special needs who (a) require an income supplement for the rest of their life and (b) are expected to live beyond their parent's death. ** Situations where liquid assets are needed when the insured dies. Examples could include those who will owe estate taxes at their death and do not want to liquidate assets to pay the taxes, or to fund a buy-sell agreement in a closely held business. ** Individuals with very high incomes who live in high-tax states may find that the after-tax return on permanent life insurance is attractive compared to alternative fixed income investments. ** Note that the large commissions paid to agents generally make permanent life insurance a poor choice for short-term savings, due to surrender charges (on a universal life policy) or low early cash values (on a whole life policy). But over a longer time horizon, the pre-tax performance of permanent life insurance (excluding variable universal life) will tend to be similar to conservative fixed-income investments. Hence, savers with high income tax rates who have an asset allocation that includes fixed income may benefit from permanent life insurance. Further note that equities held in a taxable brokerage account already have significant tax advantages, and therefore placing equities inside a variable universal life policy is generally not advisable. * '''When is group life appropriate''' - Majority opinion is that an employee should elect any group life benefit that is offered for "free" by an employer. Under US tax law, premiums for group life benefits of $50,000 or less are not taxable income to the employee. However, majority opinion is that primary insurance coverage should generally be provided by an individual life policy, rather than a group policy, since the group life insurance will terminate when the employee leaves the employer. (See additional comments on group life [[Life insurance#Further information on group life insurance|below]])
== Further information on group life insurance == Group life insurance premiums are typically based on the average mortality risk of all eligible members of the group, rather than being customized to the health of a particular insured. An employee in good health can often find comparable coverage for a lower premium in the private market, making group insurance (beyond any "free" amount provided by the employer) a relatively poor financial choice. However, an employee who is at higher risk may find that group insurance is less expensive than insurance in the private market, and might weigh these savings against the risk of leaving the group and losing coverage (or having to pay the higher "conversion" premium).
Some amount of group life insurance is often "guaranteed issue" to eligible members of the group. For example, new employees may be guaranteed the right to purchase X times their salary in coverage during the first 30 days of employment. This feature makes group insurance a useful option for insureds whose health makes them uninsurable in the private market.
==Determining family life insurance needs== This worksheet assumes that both spouses are working and will continue to work if one partner dies prematurely. Replacing 100% of your after-tax income may be a good starting place. This should leave the survivor with the same standard of living. Some expenses go down when one partner dies but other expenses, such as childcare, usually go up.

==Locating a lost policy== If you’ve lost a loved one, determining if a life insurance exists, or obtaining the details of an existing policy, may be difficult. Here are a few suggestions: * '''Search personal records:''' Look through files, safe deposit boxes and other areas where your loved one might have kept insurance documents.<ref name="insure">{{Cite web|url=https://www.insure.com/life-insurance/lost-policies.html|title=How to find lost life insurance policies |format= |page=|publisher=Insure.com|date = December 19, 2019|accessdate=28 Jan 2020}}</ref> **If the policy is not evident, try to find the name of the life insurance company that issued the policy. For clues, go through bank and credit card statements to look for evidence of premium payments made to an insurance company.<ref name="iii">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iii.org/article/how-can-i-locate-lost-life-insurance-policy|title=12 steps for locating a lost life insurance policy|format=|page=|publisher=Insurance Information Institute, Inc.|accessdate=28 Jan 2020}}</ref> * '''Contact financial advisors:''' Present or prior attorneys, accountants, investment advisors, bankers, business insurance agents/brokers and other financial professionals might have information about the deceased’s life insurance policies.<ref name="iii" /> * '''Check with employers:''' Contact the employee benefits administrators of your relative's former employers to see if any group life insurance policies are still in effect or if your loved one purchased additional voluntary coverage at work.<ref name="insure" /> * '''Check the mail:''' Look for premium notices or dividend notices. If a policy has been paid up, there will no notice of premium payments due; however, the company may still send an annual notice regarding the status of the policy or notice of a dividend.<ref name="iii" /> * '''Review income tax returns:''' Life insurance companies pay interest on accumulations on permanent policies and charge interest on policy loans.<ref name="iii" />
Insurance companies will assist you to locate a lost policy. All you need is the name of the insurer that issued the policy; from there you can contact the insurer to start a claim, even if you don’t know the policy number. A list of policy locators is in the section [[#Lost policy finders|below]].
If you are unsure a policy exists, or you don’t know the name of the insurance company, the NAIC (National Association of Insurance Commissioners) provides a free policy locator that will place inquiries with participating companies. Start here: [https://eapps.naic.org/life-policy-locator/#/welcome Life Insurance Policy Locator Service]
Insurance companies are obligated to find policy beneficiaries. If no beneficiaries are found, they are required by law to turn unclaimed funds over to the state (called "escheatment").<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metlife.com/policyfinder/|title=Policy Finder |format= |page=|publisher=Metropolitan Life Insurance Company|date = |accessdate=28 Jan 2020}}</ref>
The unclaimed funds are turned over into your state's unclaimed property division. Insurance companies turn policy proceeds over to these divisions when they know the insured person has died but can't find the beneficiary. The National Association of Unclaimed Property Administrators website provides links to unclaimed property divisions in each state. See: [https://unclaimed.org/search-for-your-unclaimed-property-its-free/ Search for your unclaimed property]<ref name="insure" />

This differs from regular life insurance in that the surviving partner doesn't receive any benefits after their spouse dies. Thus, second-to-die insurance is used for estate planning. Parents who take out this type of insurance are thinking of their children, not themselves. For example, it could be designed to pay estate taxes or support any surviving children. It is also called "Dual-Life Insurance" and "Survivorship Insurance".|[http://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/secondtodieinsurance.asp Investopedia]}} ===Irrevocable insurance trusts=== {{quotation|An irrevocable trust set up with a life insurance policy as the asset, allowing the grantor of the policy to exempt asset away from his or her taxable estate. Once the life insurance policy is placed in the trust, the insured person no longer owns the policy, which will be managed by the trustee on behalf of the policy beneficiaries when the insured person dies. The insurance trust, or irrevocable life insurance trust (ILIT), is often used to set aside cash proceeds that can be used to pay estate taxes, as the life insurance policy should be exempt from the taxable estate of the decedent. One catch on the insurance trust is that the life insurance policy must be transferred to the trust at least three years before the death of the insured. To get around this rule, a new policy can be taken out with a spouse as owner, then placed in the trust. As an irrevocable trust, changes can only be made by beneficiaries; the owner gives up all control to the trustee. {{Notice | Life insurance products are complex in terms of pricing, contractual clauses, and taxation. This is a simplified overview of life insurance characteristics. Please ask in the forum for advice on any specific situations. Additional information can be found under ''External links'' [[#External links | below]]. }} '''Life insurance''' is a contract between the insured, the owner (who may also be the insured), and a life insurance company. The owner pays a stipulated premium to the insurance company. If the insured dies while the policy is in force a death benefit is paid to the beneficiary. Some policies accumulate cash value which is available by loan or upon surrender to the owner. Also, some policies have accelerated death benefits which may be available if the insured is expected to die within six months to a year.<ref>Definition of life insurance by forum member mephistophles (Lee E. Marshall), a Chartered Life Underwriter (CLU)</ref>
== Types of Life Insurance == Life insurance can broadly be divided into three general categories - "term", "permanent", and "group". Term life insurance is usually intended for "temporary" insurance needs, such as insuring a family breadwinner while others are dependent on his/her income. Permanent life insurance is usually intended for "lifetime" insurance needs or cash accumulation. Group life insurance is usually provided through an employer or other association, as opposed to term and permanent which are sold to individuals.
* '''Term life insurance''' usually provides a level death benefit for a certain number of years, at a premium rate guaranteed for the term period. For example, a typical 20 year term policy would provide a level death benefit, such as $1 million, for a period of 20 years, in exchange for a premium of $X per year. Level term insurance is typically sold for periods of 10-30 years, with the most popular periods being 15 and 20 years. (Note that a small number of term life insurance policies are sold with premiums that rise every year, 5 years, etc., and/or with death benefits that decrease over time.) Most policies sold as "level term life insurance" actually continue beyond the initial premium guarantee period at a much higher premium, but the insured can lapse the policy at any time and is not obligated to pay the much higher "post-level" premium rate. * '''Permanent life insurance''' provides a death benefit for the entirety of the insured's life. There are several types of permanent life insurance, as follows: ** '''Whole life insurance''' has a premium and death benefit that is fixed and guaranteed to be level for life. Because the chances of death increase as time goes on, the premiums paid in the early years are in excess of the probability of death, and therefore a "cash value" builds up within the policy over time. The policyholder can typically access the cash value by surrendering the policy, which terminates the insurance coverage, and can also take out "policy loans" from the insurance company, based on the security of the cash value. Most whole life policies are sold by "mutual" life insurance companies, and pay non-guaranteed "policyholder dividends" on an annual basis, which reduce the net cost of the whole life policy. The policyholder dividends can be used to reduce future premium payments, purchase additional insurance coverage, or just accumulate within the policy. ** '''Universal life''' is the general name for several life insurance products that utilize an "account value", which is a notional account maintained by the insurance company. Premiums paid by the policyholder are added to the account value (net of any premium loads). Deductions from the account value are made by the insurance company, generally on a monthly basis, for cost of insurance charges, rider charges, and any other expense loads. Additional credits to the account value are made with respect to interest or equity market returns on the account value. A universal life policy generally remains in force as long as the account value is positive, and lapses if the account value drops to zero. Most universal life products have "surrender charges" in the early durations of the policy, which reduce the amount available to the policyholder for loan or surrender. The policyholder can access the account value (net of surrender charges) by fully surrendering the policy, which terminates the insurance coverage, by making a "partial surrender" of the account value, or by taking out a policy loan. Within the general category of universal life, there are several distinct products as follows: *** '''Traditional universal life''' (or just plain "universal life" or "UL") credits interest to the account value at a rate declared by the company. The interest rate credited is guaranteed to not fall below a rate guaranteed in the policy (often 3%, but may be lower or higher). *** '''Indexed universal life''' (often referred to as "IUL") credits interest to the account value based on the performance of an external index, such as the S&P 500. The interest credited is limited by "caps" and "participation rates" declared by the insurance company. Usually, the interest credit is guaranteed to be not less than zero, even if the external index declines. *** '''Guaranteed universal life''' (often referred to as "GUL") works similar to traditional universal life. However, there is a "secondary guarantee" that the policy will not lapse, even if the account value falls below zero, so long as the premiums required by the policy are paid. GUL policies typically build minimal or zero cash values, and are therefore less expensive per dollar of death benefit than other types of permanent life insurance. *** '''Variable universal life''' (often referred to as "VUL") works similar to traditional universal life. However, rather than having the account value invested in the general funds of the insurance company, it is invested in mutual funds chosen by the policyholder. The account value can decline from year to year if the mutual funds decline in value. * '''Group life insurance''' is a product usually offered through an employer. It generally does not build cash values. Amounts offered may be a flat amount (such as $50,000 of death benefit), or a percentage of salary (typically 1X or 2X salary, subject to a maximum amount). Some employers offer additional amount of life insurance on a "voluntary" basis, often subject to individual underwriting. Group life coverage typically ends when the employment relationship ends, but most plans allow the employee to "convert" to an individual life insurance policy, usually at an extremely high premium. Many employers partially or fully pay the cost of group life insurance on their employees. Group life insurance is also offered through professional organizations such as engineers or accountants, often at very attractive premium rates. (See additional comments on group life insurance [[Life insurance#Further information on group life insurance|below]].)
== Purchasing individual life insurance == Most individual life insurance is sold through independent brokers or "tied" agents, while a few companies sell "direct to consumer".
* '''Independent brokers''' are "appointed" as agents for a number of life insurance companies, which allows them to submit applications for life insurance to the companies with which they are licensed. Such brokers often “shop” the coverage for a prospective insured to a number of different life insurers, trying to win the most favorable terms for their clients. While most independent brokers operate in a limited geographic area, some have established internet websites to allow them to solicit clients nationwide. * '''"Captive" agents''' primarily write life insurance for one life insurance company with which they are associated. Often the insurance company provides such agents with training, office space, etc. Such agents may also write a limited amount of business for other companies. Most captive agents are affiliated either with mutual life insurance companies, or with company groups that write both property and casualty insurance (homeowners, auto, etc.) and life insurance. * '''"Direct to consumer"''' sales use life insurance company employees who are also licensed as insurance agents to write applications for prospective policyholders.
Brokers and captive agents are usually compensated by commissions which are paid by the insurance company and whose cost is built into the pricing of the product. Life insurance commissions are generally “heaped” toward the first policy year, with renewal commissions at a much lower rate.
Depending on the amount of life insurance applied for and the age/health of the prospective insured, the life insurer might require a limited physical examination as a part of the application and underwriting process. For younger insureds and lower face amounts, the insurer might rely solely upon a questionnaire and an examination of medical and prescription drug records. Based on the underwriting review, the insurer will slot the applicant into a risk class, with lower premiums being charged to “better” risk classes. Certain conditions, usually medical in nature, might cause the insurer to assess “substandard” premiums in excess of the standard quoted rate. The insurer also might decline to provide coverage to a prospective insured if the underwriting results are quite unfavorable. Insurers may view underwriting conditions differently, so agents may consider multiple insurers so that they can find the best rate for prospective insureds.
By law, the rates for any specific life insurance policy are identical no matter how the policy is bought. That is, the policy that is bought from "Company A", assuming the same specifications, will have the identical premium and terms whether you buy it through "Agent A", "Agent B", or any website.
Most life insurers have ratings from a firm called [https://web.ambest.com/home AM Best], which rates all insurance companies. The majority of companies that are competitively active in writing life insurance have ratings from AM Best of A- or higher, which should be adequately conservative for all life insurance policies except the very largest, where the insured might choose to divide coverage between two or more companies. Other rating agencies that cover insurance companies include Fitch Ratings, Standard & Poor's, and Moody’s, but not all life insurers have ratings from each of the agencies.
== Tax treatment of life insurance == Under US tax law, death benefits from all types of life insurance are generally not taxable income to the beneficiary. Also, life insurance premiums are generally not a deductible expense.
For permanent life insurance policies, the growth in policy cash value is excluded from income, even though such growth may represent an increase in the policyholder's wealth. Cash surrenders from a permanent life insurance policy are ordinary taxable income to the extent that the cash surrender amount is in excess of the "basis" of the policy (generally the cumulative premiums paid). In the case of partial surrenders, amounts received are treated first as a return of basis, with tax owed only on additional surrenders in excess of basis. Further, as with loans against most kinds of assets, loans secured by permanent life insurance policies are not treated as taxable income.
In some rare cases, a permanent life insurance policy may be classified as a "modified endowment contract" (MEC). In those cases, partial surrenders are taxed as income until all gain in the policy has been removed, and only then are partial surrenders taxed as a return of basis. Further, loans secured by modified endowment contracts are treated as surrenders or distributions. Most policyholders and life insurers endeavor to avoid having policies classified as modified endowment contracts.
For US federal [[Estate and inheritance tax|estate and gift tax purposes]], which as of 2023 affects estates of single individuals in excess of $12.92 million, death benefit proceeds from life insurance policies are generally includable in the decedent’s gross estate and hence are generally subject to the estate tax. Some families take steps to avoid this outcome, such as having other family members or specially designed “irrevocable life insurance trusts” own life insurance policies.
== Boglehead view of life insurance products == Based on observation of posts to the Boglehead Forum, following is the general view of Bogleheads on the topic of life insurance.
* '''Need for life insurance''' - Majority opinion is that life insurance is an appropriate financial tool for a person who has someone else dependent on their income and/or survival; for example, the breadwinner of a family or a parent caring for a child. However, life insurance is not generally recommended for a person who has no one dependent on their income or survival; for example, a single person with no dependents, or a child. * '''When is term life insurance appropriate''' - Majority opinion is that term life insurance is appropriate for the vast majority of life insurance needs, including, but not limited to: ** A family with young children might choose to insure the breadwinner(s) for a duration until the children are in college or on their own, to provide for the income that would be lost if the breadwinner were to die while the children are dependent. ** A family might also choose to insure a non-working parent, reflecting the additional cost of childcare or reduced income from the other parent if the non-working parent were to die while the children are dependent. ** A breadwinner might be insured to bridge to retirement, pension benefits, or Social Security availability for a non-working spouse. ** Note that some may choose to "ladder" term life insurance policies, purchasing (for example) both a 10 year and 20 year policy, to provide more insurance during the first 10 years and reduced coverage thereafter as needs change and the assets of the family increase. * '''When is permanent life insurance appropriate''' - Majority opinion is that permanent life insurance is appropriate for only a relatively small subset of the population. Such situations include, but are not limited to: ** Those who have children with special needs who (a) require an income supplement for the rest of their life and (b) are expected to live beyond their parent's death. ** Situations where liquid assets are needed when the insured dies. Examples could include those who will owe estate taxes at their death and do not want to liquidate assets to pay the taxes, or to fund a buy-sell agreement in a closely held business. ** Individuals with very high incomes who live in high-tax states may find that the after-tax return on permanent life insurance is attractive compared to alternative fixed income investments. ** Note that the large commissions paid to agents generally make permanent life insurance a poor choice for short-term savings, due to surrender charges (on a universal life policy) or low early cash values (on a whole life policy). But over a longer time horizon, the pre-tax performance of permanent life insurance (excluding variable universal life) will tend to be similar to conservative fixed-income investments. Hence, savers with high income tax rates who have an asset allocation that includes fixed income may benefit from permanent life insurance. Further note that equities held in a taxable brokerage account already have significant tax advantages, and therefore placing equities inside a variable universal life policy is generally not advisable. * '''When is group life appropriate''' - Majority opinion is that an employee should elect any group life benefit that is offered for "free" by an employer. Under US tax law, premiums for group life benefits of $50,000 or less are not taxable income to the employee. However, majority opinion is that primary insurance coverage should generally be provided by an individual life policy, rather than a group policy, since the group life insurance will terminate when the employee leaves the employer. (See additional comments on group life [[Life insurance#Further information on group life insurance|below]])
== Further information on group life insurance == Group life insurance premiums are typically based on the average mortality risk of all eligible members of the group, rather than being customized to the health of a particular insured. An employee in good health can often find comparable coverage for a lower premium in the private market, making group insurance (in excess of any "free" amount provided by the employer) a relatively poor financial choice. However, an employee who is at higher risk may find that group insurance is less expensive than insurance in the private market, and might weigh these savings against the risk of leaving the group and losing coverage (or having to pay the higher "conversion" premium).
Some amount of group life insurance is often "guaranteed issue" to eligible members of the group. For example, new employees may be guaranteed the right to purchase X times their salary in coverage during the first 30 days of employment. This feature makes group insurance a useful option for insureds whose health makes them uninsurable in the private market.
==Determining family life insurance needs==
There are several ways to calculate your life insurance need, spanning a range of accuracy and complexity.
===Income multiplier===
The simplest way to estimate life insurance need is to multiply income by some factor. Some sources suggest '''ten times''' annual income<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/articles/pf/06/insureneeds.asp | title=How Much Life Insurance Should You Have?| publisher=Investopedia| accessdate=Feb 22, 2025}}</ref>. As an alternative, you could assume a [[Safe withdrawal rates|safe withdrawal rate]] on the lump sum, likely in the 3-4% range, which would give a multiplier in the 25-33x range. This is likely a conservative estimate, as it assumes a very high probability that the principal will not be exhausted, when in reality it might be okay for the surviving spouse to draw the principal down.
When determining need for a non-working spouse, their "income" would be the cost to hire help to replace the work they do that would not be taken on by the surviving spouse.
===Worksheet method===
This worksheet assumes that both spouses are working and will continue to work if one partner dies prematurely. Replacing 100% of your after-tax income may be a good starting place. This should leave the survivor with the same standard of living. Some expenses go down when one partner dies but other expenses, such as childcare, usually go up.

===Detailed plan===
The most accurate way to determine life insurance need is to create a detailed year-by-year plan for each spouse, assuming the other spouse passed away, from the present until a predicted date of financial independence. A complete plan would consider things like:
*the desired living situation and standard of living of the surviving family<ref group="note">Due to the heavy emotional burden that will likely result from the death of a spouse and parent, it would be reasonable to plan for changing as few things as possible, including remaining in the family house and maintaining the same standard of living. Emotional trauma for children will likely be minimized if they can have the same home, school, friends, and activities. In some situations, it could make sense to plan specific changes, such as moving to be closer to relatives. It could also be reasonable to plan to curtail some luxury spending, such as buying less expensive cars, flying economy instead of business-class, or suspending expensive hobbies.</ref> *current available assets and debts, and the plans to tap them or pay them off *the expected rate of return on invested assets, including the lump-sum life insurance payout *loss of income and non-paying work from the dying spouse, including loss of benefits (especially health insurance and retirement contributions) *potential employment for the surviving spouse, which could include taking time off from current employment to deal with the loss, or seeking a job even if they do not have one now *removal of expenses for the dying spouse - food, cars, hobbies, etc. *final expenses - funeral, burial, etc. *expected future expenses, such as higher education for children *change in tax liability, including a change to [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/q/qualified-widow-or-widower.asp Qualified Widower] status for two years, then [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/h/head_of_household.asp Head of Household], and possibly Single later on *available Social Security survivor benefits<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.ssa.gov/pubs/EN-05-10084.pdf | title=Survivors Benefits| publisher=IRS| accessdate=Feb 22, 2025}}</ref> *the likelihood the surviving spouse would remarry (or whether this possibility should be considered at all)
===Rounding up===
Due to the uncertainties involved, low cost of term life, and likely negative consequences of a shortfall, standard financial advice is to generously round up both the amount of insurance and the term. For example, if your analysis says you should purchase $1.6M of coverage for a term of 24 years, a $2.0M 30-year would be prudent. Term policies can always be canceled early if your insurance need is gone before you planned. But if you are behind your plan for reasons that might or might not be under your control, purchasing more coverage later in life will likely be difficult and very expensive.
===Layering policies===
Most people's need for life insurance decreases over time, as they build assets, pay off debts, and put expenses behind them. Therefore, it may be a potential savings in premiums to ''layer'' several life insurance policies. For example, if you need $3M in life insurance today and expect to be financially independent in 30 years, you could purchase a $1M 20-year policy, a $1M 25-year policy, and a $1M 30-year policy. These three policies will likely be cheaper than a single $3M 30-year policy. The cost savings may or may not be worth the added complexity. Also consider that some expenses the policy is meant to cover, especially higher education for children, may be weighted toward the end of the term.
Buying policies at different insurers can provide diversification against insolvency at any one insurer.
==Locating a lost policy== If you’ve lost a loved one, determining if a life insurance exists, or obtaining the details of an existing policy, may be difficult. Here are a few suggestions: * '''Search personal records:''' Look through files, safe deposit boxes and other areas where your loved one might have kept insurance documents.<ref name="insure">{{Cite web|url=https://www.insure.com/life-insurance/lost-policies.html|title=How to find lost life insurance policies |format= |page=|publisher=Insure.com|date = December 19, 2019|accessdate=28 Jan 2020}}</ref> **If the policy is not evident, try to find the name of the life insurance company that issued the policy. For clues, go through bank and credit card statements to look for evidence of premium payments made to an insurance company.<ref name="iii">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iii.org/article/how-can-i-locate-lost-life-insurance-policy|title=12 steps for locating a lost life insurance policy|format=|page=|publisher=Insurance Information Institute, Inc.|accessdate=28 Jan 2020}}</ref> * '''Contact financial advisors:''' Present or prior attorneys, accountants, investment advisors, bankers, business insurance agents/brokers and other financial professionals might have information about the deceased’s life insurance policies.<ref name="iii" /> * '''Check with employers:''' Contact the employee benefits administrators of your relative's former employers to see if any group life insurance policies are still in effect or if your loved one purchased additional voluntary coverage at work.<ref name="insure" /> * '''Check the mail:''' Look for premium notices or dividend notices. If a policy has been paid up, there will no notice of premium payments due; however, the company may still send an annual notice regarding the status of the policy or notice of a dividend.<ref name="iii" /> * '''Review income tax returns:''' Life insurance companies pay interest on accumulations on permanent policies and charge interest on policy loans.<ref name="iii" />
Insurance companies will assist you to locate a lost policy. All you need is the name of the insurer that issued the policy; from there you can contact the insurer to start a claim, even if you don’t know the policy number. A list of policy locators is in the section [[#Lost policy finders|below]].
If you are unsure a policy exists, or you don’t know the name of the insurance company, the NAIC (National Association of Insurance Commissioners) provides a free policy locator that will place inquiries with participating companies. Start here: [https://eapps.naic.org/life-policy-locator/#/welcome Life Insurance Policy Locator Service]
Insurance companies are obligated to find policy beneficiaries. If no beneficiaries are found, they are required by law to turn unclaimed funds over to the state (called "escheatment").<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metlife.com/policyfinder/|title=Policy Finder |format= |page=|publisher=Metropolitan Life Insurance Company|date = |accessdate=28 Jan 2020}}</ref>
The unclaimed funds are turned over into your state's unclaimed property division. Insurance companies turn policy proceeds over to these divisions when they know the insured person has died but can't find the beneficiary. The National Association of Unclaimed Property Administrators website provides links to unclaimed property divisions in each state. See: [https://unclaimed.org/search-for-your-unclaimed-property-its-free/ Search for your unclaimed property]<ref name="insure" />
